/COMMIT_MSG.message: How about "Disable rt throttling the right way"

Say something like:

"Currently sched_rt_period_us and sched_rt_runtime_us are set to equal values, essentially disabling rt throttling.  But setting sched_rt_runtime_us to -1 is the preferred way of disabling throttling, so that's what we do here now."
Any suggestion of a valid testcase? Thanks.

It's more than that, with -1 there are chunks of code that get skipped entirely which will be more efficient.  It may also reduce the number of interrupts of a busy-looping userspace process, I'd have to check to see for sure.

Also, the commit message needs to describe the testing that has been done.

Read /proc/sys/kernel/sched_rt_runtime_us and check that it's set to -1.

Start a busy-looping process, use "taskset" to put it on an application CPU, use "chrt" to set it to realtime priority, ensure it gets 100% of the CPU.

global-requirements.txt.message:
upper-constraints already constrains this below this version. We shouldn't need to add this constraint in global-requirements.

It is also very difficult to remove these constraints once newer versions are available, so it should be avoided as much as possible.

Maybe if your commit message actually stated what/why this is being done it would help, but with upper-constraints this shouldn't be needed.

That's a good point. I didn't put the constraint in upper-constraints because there were cases when upper-constraints use blocked CI. At the time one of the mitigations was to drop upper-constraints from tox environments. 
Since we need to cap validations-libs at <1.7.0 setting the constraint in requirements.txt, and therefore in the globals seemed like the only approach that would cover all cases.

It's possible that the situation was resolved in the meantime, I'll look into that and change the patch accordingly if that is the case.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think we should do this other way around. We want them deprecations for a reason. So if operator actually reads releasenotes and spots the default have changed they could flip the config option and suppress the warnings. If not they would get very visible reminder on the service logs.

Even better if we would emit these warnings when the policy engine loads the rules rather than every request. As in full list of deprecations on service start and then just work without spamming.

Obviously we should turn the warnings off in gate/tests. But what's the point of deprecation if you don't tell the operator that something changed?

> Even better if we would emit these warnings when the policy engine loads the rules rather than every request. As in full list of deprecations on service start and then just work without spamming.

FWIW, there was a patch up to make the deprecation logs less spammy: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.policy/+/674711

As I recall, it was only somewhat helpful because every policy got logged in every API thread/process anyway because they all had separate copies of the enforcer. It's also possible I don't remember correctly because that was two years ago. :-)

Also, note the commit message on https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.policy/+/673932/ which discusses why these knobs weren't originally in oslo.policy. The intent was that projects would use the warning filters to address this (as in set the filter to log warnings only once).

yeah and in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.policy/+/717879 we added a new flag to handle/stop wanrning for default change (and keep warn on name change) 'suppress_default_change_warnings' and most of the projects started disabling those - https://codesearch.opendev.org/?q=suppress_default_change_warnings&i=nope&files=&excludeFiles=&repos=

so default change warnings are disabled via hardcoded flag 'suppress_default_change_warnings' and operator has to way to enable those. In this commit, I am making that as configurable so that operator can enable those.

I will add TODO note in the code that we can enable these warning by default once we remove the legacy policy rules (means current policy change of all the rule defaults).

for regular default change I agree we should add warning by default but during new RBAC work every policy rule is changing its default so its too much warnings. that is why I thought of disable it by default as thousands of warnings does not help in case of new RBAC migration.
We can close https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.policy/+bug/1836568 with this patch.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I would like to know if this patch is still relevant?
Ok thanks a lot for your answer.
Yeah, I was waiting for the PTG discussion abd how we decide to enable the new defaults/scope by default. We have more clarity now, let me revise it.

oslo_policy/opts.py.message: Imo we should default this to the old behaviour, some optimization ideas in the commit message comment.

I am on the fence on setting this default "False" because it will also stop warnings for non-"secure RBAC" related default value changes that may be important for the operator to be aware of.
This would mean that the only way for a project to notify the operator of a default value change would be via the release notes.
On the other hand, the "secure RBAC" changes are causing hugely excessive logging.

Yeah, I have added a TODO (L48) to fix that. As of now, all projects are changing the policy default for 'secure RBAC' only and so its warning will be disabled by default. But once we are going to finish the 'secure RBAC' then we can default it to True.

We do have operators that rely on logs to figure out what to do with policies (e.g., kinda like crafting SElinux policies).

Disabling this by default seems like it's going against that mentality. Is it possible to log a warning once?

I wonder if we should handle the cleanup of leftover Ports outside this Semaphore. The creation of other Ports will take longer if we also lock the deletion. Well, you're right. Even so neutron have a hard time during the bulk create request, it'll be not much better, if we throw at it several delete requests. Maybe we should just relay on the periodic task for that?

Yes, just consider the case we've seen with networks - even though we've always attempted to list networks by name, we still duplicated them because Neutron was still processing the request. I'm pretty sure this can happen with ports too, so I'm not convinced it makes sense to attempt a cleanup immediately. Maybe some task deferred for a few minutes would work too, but then I'm not sure I see any advantage of that compared to just waiting for the periodic.
Ok, so that means, we need to wait a bit for port set (or a subset) to be created, and then remove the ports by running periodic task, is that correct?

Deletes are pretty cheap in Neutron world. The problem here is that this mainly targets issue of 504 timeouts on Neutron API and in that case when we'll query to list ports just after the request fails, the ports will most likely still be missing from the list.

So digging back through the rsyslog mailing list, this changed in 2020, about a year after the log offloading patch was added to Octavia. I guess local queuing is no longer an option.

doc/source/admin/log-offloading.rst.message: So previously the amphora rsyslog would buffer up to a certain number of messages before failing over to the other server, does the amp continue to buffer messages locally? If so, under what conditions?

Before the change https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/octavia/+/831203 rsyslog failover was broken in the amp. With UDP it would just never fail over and with TCP the previous rsyslog configuration generated by Octavia did not work with multiple servers (https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2009876). Rsyslog clients do not support the "one queue per action" configuration like it was before. See https://www.rsyslog.com/doc/master/tutorials/failover_syslog_server.html.

Regarding buffering: The queues are still there and buffer messages. Failover does not depend on how many messages are in the queues, but on the number of "connection refused" errors the client sees. log_retry_interval defines after which time interval a failed server gets tried again. Buffering itself works like before.

No, that is my point and concern here. This did work and was taken directly from the rsyslog documentation, so I'm a bit concerned that there is a major change in behavior here.
Obviously UDP could not fail over, and this was documented in the previous version. But TCP supported server failover and with buffering.
Something has changed here that is confusing.

octavia/api/v2/controllers/l7policy.py.message: + HTTPS? HTTPS is HTTPS passthrough so the URL is encrypted. We could get the server name present in the ClientHello packet if the SNI extension is enabled and so apply a subset of the L7 rules but I'm not sure we can do that today in the amphora provider at least.
IIRC it would require the HTTPS connection to be terminated and the payload decrypted, which is out of bounds for a 'passthrough' connection.

The api-ref says:

"The HTTPS protocol is HTTPS pass-through. For most providers, this is treated as a TCP protocol. Some advanced providers may support HTTPS session persistence features by using the session ID." https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/load-balancer/v2/index.html#protocol-combinations-listener-pool

So my guess is that if a provider can support session persistence for HTTPS pass-through, it can also support some L7Rules on unencrypted data (certificate or SSL headers).

Done.
But I'm wondering if a 3rd party provider can implement l7 policies in a pass-through https LB.

Putting more thought into this, and following-up to my earlier comment, this is a limitation to the amphora provider. Other providers may be able to do L7 policing (e.g. server name present in the ClientHello packet). So, it would be unfair to disallow others to support L7 policy on HTTPS listeners just because the amphora provider cannot do it today.

Best would be to extend the amphora provider driver to validate this scenario and raise UnsupportedOptionError. For example, see how the it validates pool algorithms in https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/955bb8840616d96ed74de3086f8959ad4190a472/octavia/api/drivers/amphora_driver/v1/driver.py#L154

This is a fair point and thank you for thinking of the drivers needs.
I think this is a case where we need to decide what the API documents and supports vs. future features.
We know there are L7 cases for TLS, etc. in fact our engine supports them, it's just that feature hasn't been implemented yet.
Looking at the L7 rules we support, I think the only ones that would match for non-http protocols would be the SSL_* rule types, but we also don't support TLS offload for TCP flows.
Currently we don't test these in any way either (API tests, etc.).
So, I think we also need to update the API documentation and be more explicit about the current capability of the API.
With that documentation, I am ok adding this, then in the future allowing a new feature that enables L7 processing of non-HTTP listeners.

octavia_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/v2.message: LGTM the test would be skipped if the provider doesn't support connection_limit

question: did you try a non-threaded approach (I would like to avoid such complexity in the code)? we could create <n> sessions, then perform sequentially requests on each session, the behavior would be the same.

Hi Tom!

That was fast, thanks for review :-)

In term of this particular test patch I don't see any special reason for replacing the "Thread" with "concurrent.futures".


Thanks!

That's right, the result would be the same from the Octavia point of view, means that at least X/2 of the total X concurrent TCP connections are expected to be dropped.

The major challenge of this test, is that we need to get the exact feedback from each one of the concurrently initiated TCP connections, to consider if the particular TCP connection succeed or not and this is why I've chosen Threading module. 
Here is an example list representing 10 threads results and that is used for test's assertion: http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/1017144

The test is stable (I've ran it for ~10 times), Threading is a built in Python module and I'm not sure that non-threaded way will avoid code complexity.
Did you consider using the concurrent.futures module instead? It makes managing threads a bit less error prone IMO.
I don't mind the threads, but Greg is right, this could be significantly simplified to just open multiple sessions.

If you just need to test if one or two more will fail, why launch all of these extra threads? It wastes RAM and CPU cycles that could be used for other tests.
This is launching 10 threads, all making requests multiple times (a total of 100 requests!).
I think we need to scale this back and consider the impact this test would have on test runtime and resource usage.
This test could use just a connection limit of 1 and then two connections to validate the limit is functioning.

OK, in order to reduce CPU and RAM usage I can set the connection_limit=1 and threads=2.
I'm a bit skeptic about setting the connection_limit=1, what about the concurrent traffic tests?
Theoretically some of them may fail because of dropped connections.

octavia_tempest_plugin/tests/validators..message: This is marked as file private with the "_" prefix, but it's called from the traffic ops suite. Let's make this consistent with the other validation methods here.
Is there anyway we can use the validate_URL_response method above instead of adding another connection method?

OK, technically it's doable, but by using "validate_URL_response" I'll have to set the only expected code to "200" and for the purpose of this specific test (connection limit) any received status code would be fine.

I don't think that raising "InvalidHttpSuccessCode" error on any other code different than "200 OK" and failing the "test_connection_limit" because of that, is the a correct logic for this particular connection limit test.

(Sorry for my late comment.)

Given your finding that polling the output of the "ip link show dev <dev>" command can be used to determine when the interface is really up, perhaps we can modify this function to do the same as well. (I had used the "operstate" file because I was not aware of the aforementioned option.)

This would avoid unnecessary delays with network adapters that are not connected (i.e., when there is no link).

Unfortunately this was not possible. I wrote a script to poll an interface to test for this specific scenario. Checking the administrative state through 'ip link show dev <dev>', /operstate and /speed:

52: ADM->UP OPER->down SPD->-1
53: ADM->UP OPER->down SPD->-1
54: ADM->UP OPER->up SPD->10000
55: ADM->UP OPER->up SPD->10000

We only get a valid speed value after the interface is fully operational. So ports where there is no link will really have to wait until timeout.

Could you put this into a _get_netdev_operstate function similar to _get_netdev_flags(), _read_flags(), I think we should use it in another place too.  We should also catch any Exception on the open()

I think we should report the operstate here as well, or have different warning message for the case of operstate=down and speed -1.  We get more than a few bugs where it's reported that this error message might be the culprit, but it's actually just a non connected port.

Replied in the general comment section.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Does the device have to be administratively up (the user saying ip link set dev <blah> up), or actually operationally up (be in running state with a carrier) to set the VFs?  I see you are checking the operstate -- what would happen if there was no cable plugged into this port?

It makes sense to me that a PF should always be administratively up before creating the VMs.  I'm not a huge fan of putting device/driver specific logic in the template file.  I wonder if it would make sense to simplify things by doing an ifdown/ifup before trying to enable _any_ device:

https://opendev.org/starlingx/stx-puppet/src/branch/master/puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/manifests/network.pp#L283

Hi,

Just to clarify, when preparing initial versions of these patches to get the integration going, I did not consider the difference between administrative and operational states.

My main goal was to ensure that the interface was really administratively up prior to attempting to setting up the virtual function interfaces, because the driver reports an error otherwise.

It takes about one (1) second for the interface to be administratively up, but the request appears to be handled asynchronously, so simply waiting for "ip link set <IFACE> up" to exit does /not/ appear to be sufficient, at least in my tests.

Hence, I used the operational state to guarantee that the interface is administratively fully up, prior to setting up VFs.

However, as Steven points out, I did not consider disconnected interfaces while doing so... If there are many disconnected interfaces on the host, the delays will add up. I do not know how problematic the additional delay would be.

I unfortunately have not had the time/chance to investigate why the administrative state change is handled asynchronously by the driver.
Ok I see via looking at https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/config/+/836958/2/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/interface.py#b1039 that we are currently setting the # of VFs as a PRE_UP operation

That was a good corner case I hadn't tested. 

I ran some tests here with a port without a cable connected it, where even after 'ip link set dev <if> up' operstate stays 'down' and carrier is '0'. Creating the VFs still works correctly. So I can confirm that it is only required that the device is administratively up.

Code logic wise this proposed solution would still work in this situation, only it would take the full 2 seconds querying operstate instead of things moving on as soon as the interface is up.
Yes, I can reproduce the issue. If we try to write to the sriov_numvfs file without the interface being at least UP (the original behavior) the VFs are not created and some error is printed in dmesg.

Hey Antonio, thanks.  Without your new change (or the operstate one), were you able to reproduce the issue with not being able to set the VFs?  Just to confirm that when we are checking for 'UP', that we're definitely able to start configuring it for SR-IOV.

Agreed on avoiding device specific logic in the template file. I modified the logic to use a flag coming from sysinv instead, so all device specific decisions are made there and puppet just follows the instructions now.

About the ifdown/ifup, while it would probably work, I believe it has a different intent than what we're aiming for. It should be used to reset an interface (which may imply in losing some configs, such as routes). For this SR-IOV scenario we just want to ensure the interface is up.

On trying to apply the same logic for any device, I posted some thoughts in the change you linked to. But even if in the future we decide to make this behavior generic, this change would still be good, we could just set the "up_requirement" flag to true always in sysinv and not have to touch puppet at all.
Made some changes to query the interface administrative state through the UP flag instead of operational. Ran some tests and this seems to work properly for interfaces with and without a carrier.
Looks good to me. Thank you!

For example:

  for port_dir in "/sys/bus/pci/devices/<%= @addr %>/net/"*; do
    if ! [ -d "${port_dir}" ]; then
      continue
    fi
    port_name="$(basename -- "${port_dir}")"

deployment/memcached/memcached-container.message: this doesn't look a correct replacement? Loopback IPs provide only a fallback if lookup returns no data.
The value is replaced by Heat while Heat processes templates to create stack resources. Thus missing value should be detected at that time, and there is no way to make this fail during deployment.
this doesn't look right to me either. we need the value here that would have been returned by hiera -c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml memcached::listen_ip.0, not the fallback value.

memcached::listen_ip.0 is defined at [1] and the logic here I'm implementing is exactly same as that logic.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/832190/1/deployment/memcached/memcached-container-puppet.yaml#207
ok, that makes sense. i was thrown off by the fact that this is just always the loopback address. The Heat calculated value for the IP address on MemcachedNetwork is not used here.

I have no horse in this race, but I agree with Takashi's reasoning. The "fallback value" only makes sense in the context of using the hiera cli tool, but we're now using heat's value which is established at L206, and the first (.0) entry is the same loopback address generated for the MEMCACHED_IP at L365.
then please make deployment failing instead of silently configuring suboptimal memcached config as a failback

These two puppet parameters(memcached:listen_ip and memcached::tcp_port) are defined in the same template and should be available in the same node. So it should not happen that these keys are not found in hieradata, so these default fallback is a kind of meaningless..

specs/xena/approved/glance/image-encrypt.message:
You can remove this.
Also need to fix following indentation issues.

I thought with the Secret Consumer API, the owner can still delete a secret with a --force option, so it's more of an extra check (which is definitely nice to have), but a user could still delete in-use secrets even with the Secret Consumer API.  I think it's worth stating this explicitly in order to make it clear that the bad scenario can occur even with the Secret Consumer API, so it's not like there's a gaping hole in the implementation if the Consumer API is not available.)

I think you'll be able to use os_glance_encrypt_key_id=UUID as a filter to the image-list request to find out if a particular secret ID is in use.

Also, I think this commit:
https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/0c45de3ed8253096bb9d4031db8e046107e2774b

will have an impact on your original spec, because it makes the 'os_glance' prefix a reserved namespace, and end users won't be allowed to create the properties needed for the feature:

https://opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs/blame/commit/c33e771b4e62267aed757849f9be063d3d5c35c0/specs/victoria/approved/glance/image-encryption.rst#L89-L94

This isn't directly related to the topic of this spec-lite, but we do need to figure out what to do about this (which I imagine will be using a different prefix for your image properties), and then amend the original spec.

I think those are fine.  The 'os_' part indicates that it has something to do with openstack, so that will help distinguish those properties.  Only 'os_glance_' properties are reserved.

You should probably put up a patch to update the original spec with the actual names you'll be using.
I looked into the WIP patch linked below. We don't use the 'os_glance' prefix but 'os_encrypt_*' and 'os_decrypt_*'. Would that be a problem too?

This already sounds more like a solution than a problem. What is the actual issue we are facing? Then in the "solution" section, describe how/why the secret consumer API from Barbican would help us solve this issue.

I'd propose we make it clear here that the feature is not considered completed and supported before the Secret Consumers part is done and it's EXPERIMENTAL (also for the reasons that we can correct the API behaviour if this work goes past Xena release). The intent for this lite-spec is speed up the development of the other components while waiting for the Secret Consumer API finishingg in Barbican.
+1. I'd like users to know that if they use this before it's been fully implemented, they might run into issues.

As I just noted on the WIP patch, there are a fair number of details to get right to make sure we don't do things out of order or ignore some error situations and leave data exposed to be lost if the key goes away. Might be worth doing a real spec to flesh out all those things, IMHO.
Agreed. I'm very worried with the fact that "[users] will have to be careful when deleting secrets". I'd like to see all the details discussed before we implement this.

nit: we can be a bit more specific; glance allows filtering on arbitrary metadata for the image-list call, so if you know the uuid of the encryption key, you can easily get a list of all images using it.

My two cents on this: if I'm not wrong, what Nova expects for "physical-direct" ports (that means PF ports) is to be able to have, in the port profile (that is a generic json string), a dictionary with mac_binding={host: mac}.

If this new extension is enabled and the port profile has this information, Neutron can return the expected MAC address (that means, mac_binding[host]), not the Neutron port DB MAC address, that will never change.

Is that correct? IMO this is doable. Of course, it is weird to have multiple MAC addresses, but there is a justification.

Sean, gibi, please, ping me whenever you want to discuss this.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/767922

On the today's drivers meeting it was agreed that this patch needs to be changed to do the override of the MAC in the OVO layer instead of the API layer. 

After the meeting I played around with that idea but I think the GET /ports/<port_id> API call does not use the port OVO to produce the API response. Bence confirmed my suspicion with [1].

In the meantime Bence raised the question that, why we don't overwrite the DB value of the port.mac_address (as suggested earlier). I think we cannot remove the logic of resetting the MAC of such port at unbind as that would re-introduce the bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1830383
I've talked this through with Rodolfo on IRC this morning: https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-neutron/%23openstack-neutron.2022-03-07.log.html#t2022-03-07T09:48:06

Gibi referred to me getting involved in the background. I was suggesting to persist the new PF MAC (received from nova in the binding:profile) into the port's proper MAC attribute. My basic reason was to follow the principle of the least surprise. This way we would not have contradictory data in the DB about the port's MAC, therefore no (internal or external) consumer of this data could ever face the challenge of how to interpret the contradictory data.

So going back to the question of persisting MAC from binding:profile to port.mac_address in the DB. 

I think it is doable. There is one downside. If the port is created with a MAC provided by the used then that MAC will be lost as soon as the port is bound as the new logic will overwrite that MAC in the port.mac_address field of the DB. When the port is unbound the neutron will generate a random MAC for the port. 

Is this acceptable?

I think we can accept this as basically nova today already make such user defined MAC lost (for direct-physical ports). As nova update the port.mac_address before the port it binds the port. Also there is a neutron logic that if such port is unbound the MAC is reset already today.

Making one step back and looking at the reality first.

When a direct-physical port is bound to a compute host the port.mac_address value is not getting programmed to the physical device. Probably it wasn't implemented as we cannot make sure we can do it for all kind of physical devices. So at this point the port.mac_address and the MAC of the PF the port is bound to differs. This is can cause confusing for the user of the port. So there was work done in nova in the past to resolve the difference by updating the port.mac_address with the MAC of the PF right before the port is bound to that PF.

However this solution is not complete as when the VM (using the port) is being moved to another host the port is re-bound to another PF with a different MAC. But that MAC is not reflected in the port.mac_address. This means that after the VM is moved the port.mac_address and the PF the port is bound to will be different again.

^^ This is where we are today on master. 

My goals is to remove the difference between the port.mac_address an the MAC of the PF the port is actually bound to.

Possible options:
A) remove the limitation from Neutron that today prevents updating port.mac_address when the port is in a bound state. This is dangerous for non direct-physical ports where the user expectation is that a change of the port.mac_address is automatically reflected on the device the port is bound to. This would be OK for direct-physical ports and nova could do the port.mac_address update during move operations.

B) Change nova in a way that during a VM move operation nova first unbound the port from the source host, changes the MAC according to the dest host PF, then bounds the port to the dest host. This is problematic for two reasons.
  i) live migration already uses multiple port binding so unbounding is not really possible as there is a passive binding on the target already
  ii) this solution opens a race condition window where another client can bound the port after nova unbound from the source host but before nova binds it to the dest host

C) Make the MAC address of the neutron port connected logically to the binding of the port instead of connected directly to the port itself. Make sure that each binding (binding:profile) of a port can specify the MAC address of the physical device (PF) the binding connects the port to. Then make sure that the port.mac_address always shows the MAC address of the active binding of the port (or show a neutron generated MAC if there is no active binding)

I prefer option C)

---

You suggestion of having a mac_binding={host: mac} structure is not necessary. The port already has a per host data structure as the port binding is always per host. This is why I suggest to handle the MAC via the binding:profile as that is already unique per host in neutron.

One can say that it is only true if multiple port binding is used. But in reality if neutron only allows a single port binding per port (if multiple port binding is disabled) then the logic still applies the binding profile is valid in the context of the host the port is bound to. (See the pci_slot bindig:profile field that is used with the same meaning today as that is also unique per host)

About the point to how we persist things in neutron I'm happy to follow the suggestion to change the patch from only showing the MAC from the profile to actually overwrite the port.mac_address in the DB according to the profile.

I'm fine with "the principle of the least surprise". I don't like easter eggs in the code.

If we make this change, based on the port profile info, we should change how we test the port MAC change in the ML2 plugin methods, considering the exception of the direct-physical ports.

This change should be IPAM compatible. There are many places in the IPAM module where the port MAC is used (just a heads-up).
I've updated the patch to overwrite the DB directly.
Summarized the discussion in the bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1942329/comments/9

Cool. So you are OK not to change the persisted port.mac_address value just overwrite it with the returned port dict (as this patch proposed). Thanks. This make the solution on the neutron side pretty simple.

Right, the port binding is per host; if we have multiple port binding, we don't need to create a mac_binding={host: mac} structure, just to add the "{mac: value}" you already added here.

If Neutron community is OK with this patch, I'm too. The Neutron DB register "port.mac" value (I explicitly said Neutron DB register as opposed to the real L1 PF MAC value) is just a random generated value. In this specific case (and probably we'll have more in the future), this value is irrelevant. As you said, we need to use the NIC MAC value defined in the HW; not all drivers allow to override this value.

Thus, if in "portbinding.profile" we have "{mac: value}" (defined by Nova in this case, as is Nova who binds the port), Neutron will override the MAC value in the generated "port" dictionary; this value is returned by the API in any call (get/list port). As you said:
* This allows to override the MAC address
* We don't shortcut the protection we have in Neutron to block the MAC change for a bound port. We are not changing the DB register "port.mac" value.
* We can handle multiple port binding with multiple MAC addresses.

Thanks for working on this!

Ack
why need to change port's mac if there is no new mac in binding profile?

If the port was bound then unbound then we need to reset the mac address of the port to a generated one as we want to avoid keeping the MAC of the existing PF in a port that is not bound to that PF any more. This is to avoid the duplicated MAC scenario when another port is being bound to that PF.

There is one edge case though. We re-generate the MAC here even if the port haven't had the PF MAC set before. But this is only possible if nova is old and does not send the MAC in the binding profile. So while it is a bit wasteful to regenerate in the MAC in this case it is will not happen in the future at all after nova is upgraded.
